function_call.name: classify_risks
function_call.arguments: {"sorted_risks":[{"name":"Inadequate consideration of water feature design in urban areas"},{"name":"Unsuitable selection of tree species in highly populated areas"},{"name":"Introduction or reestablishment of new species in urban areas fostering the transmission of vector-borne and zoonotic diseases"},{"name":"Designing water features in a way that limits mosquito breeding and algal growth, but increases the danger for children and pets"},{"name":"Maintaining undisturbed vegetation around a pond providing habitat for rats and other rodents"},{"name":"Introduction of exotic species causing new allergies among urban residents"},{"name":"High levels of air pollutants in urban areas"},{"name":"Mechanical interaction between air pollutants and pollen grains"},{"name":"High allergenicity of ornamental plant pollen"},{"name":"Overabundance of specific plant species in urban vegetation"},{"name":"Limited dispersion of pollen due to road-side tree planting"},{"name":"Increased pollen exposure due to urban green space"},{"name":"Rising prevalence and severity of pollinosis"},{"name":"Impact of climate change and air pollution on pollinosis exposure"},{"name":"Excess algal growth in urban bodies of water"},{"name":"Risks associated with rodent habitat near ponds due to undisturbed vegetation"},{"name":"Health risks associated with water toxins and algal blooms"},{"name":"Algal blooms may produce phytotoxins and hepatotoxins, leading to water contamination and health risks for humans and animals."},{"name":"Neurotoxins produced by algal blooms can affect the nervous system of exposed organisms, leading to severe health effects and potential fatality."},{"name":"Algal blooms in urban ponds may pose less of a threat to humans, but still require monitoring and management to prevent any potential risks."},{"name":"Increased overgrowth of aquatic vegetation leading to low dissolved oxygen levels and stagnant water areas"},{"name":"Excessive growth of algae and cyanobacteria in urban ponds"},{"name":"Poorly designed landscape details contributing to production of troublesome numbers of mosquitoes"},{"name":"Lack of natural predators in constructed bodies of water leading to increased mosquito populations"},{"name":"High conductivity and low dissolved oxygen content in water leading to higher mosquito larval densities"},{"name":"Constructed wet environments are the predominant producers of mosquitoes in urban areas"},{"name":"Urban wetlands and water bodies provide suitable habitat for bird species, increasing the possibility of disease transmission to human populations"},{"name":"Stagnant, shallow water is associated with high mosquito larvae counts in constructed wet environments"},{"name":"Urban water bodies and wetlands providing habitats for mosquitoes"},{"name":"High mosquito densities in constructed wet environments"},{"name":"Inefficient rodent control measures leading to increased rat populations"},{"name":"Inadequate design and management of urban green spaces"},{"name":"Introduction of open surface water in urban design"},{"name":"Increasing connectivity between green areas in modern cities could facilitate the spread of infectious diseases between geographically distant rat populations."},{"name":"The increase in biodiversity of rodent predators may foster the introduction of certain pathogens into urban landscapes."},{"name":"The presence of foxes in urban areas has increased the likelihood of the small fox tapeworm e. multilocularis occurring in city rodents and infection risk for domestic dogs and cats."},{"name":"Vector-borne diseases spread by ectoparasitic organisms on rats , lyme disease, typhus, plague"},{"name":"Increased asthma morbidity in inner-city children due to rat allergen sensitization and exposure"},{"name":"Potential contamination of urban bodies of water with infectious disease agents from rats , campylobacter, salmonella, e. coli"},{"name":"Transmission of zoonotic pathogens from urban rats to humans"},{"name":"Overpopulation of urban rats"},{"name":"Tick-borne disease prevalence in white-footed mice"},{"name":"Increased connectivity of urban green areas may lead to higher tick populations, increasing the risk of tick-borne infections in humans."},{"name":"Use of chemical sprays and applications for tick control threatens harmless non-target species and provides only temporary results."},{"name":"Inconsistent effectiveness of tick control methods in different ecological contexts, as demonstrated by the differing results of pyrethrin-soaked cotton fibers in different geographic locations."},{"name":"Increased risk of zoonotic tick-borne infections due to climate change-induced increase in tick population and expansion of their habitats."},{"name":"Conflicting impact of deer density on tick-borne infections, with some studies suggesting a reduction and others indicating an increase in infections."},{"name":"Dependency of other tick-borne diseases on the presence of deer, leading to increased risk of transmission and spread."},{"name":"Increased presence of ticks in urban green spaces"},{"name":"Zoonotic tick-borne pathogens in urban areas"}]}
